natural problem:
How many different rectangles with sides parallel to the grid can be formed by connecting four of the dots in a $4\times 4$ square array of dots, as in the figure below?
[asy]size(2cm,2cm); for (int i=0; i<4; ++i) { for (int j=0; j<4; ++j) { filldraw(Circle((i, j), .05), black, black); } } [/asy] (Two rectangles are different if they do not share all four vertices.)
natural solution: We count the number of rectangles by cases, based on the side lengths of the rectangle: \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{Side lengths of rectangle} & \text{Number of rectangles} \\ \hline 1 \times 1 & 9 \\ \hline

\] So the number of rectangles whose sides are parallel to the sides of the grid is $9+6+3+6+4+2+3+2+1 = \boxed{36}.$ Extra challenge: If you know what "combinations" are in counting problems, try to find a much faster solution!

fixes rectangles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. rectangles n = binomial n 2 ^ 2"

(* ### Problem

 1 \times 2 & 6 \\ \hline 1 \times 3 & 3 \\ \hline 2 \times 1 & 6 \\ \hline 2 \times 2 & 4 \\ \hline 2 \times 3 & 2 \\ \hline 3 \times 1 & 3 \\ \hline 3 \times 2 & 2 \\ \hline 3 \times 3 & 1 \\ \hline \end{array}
 \] So the number of rectangles whose sides are parallel to the sides of the grid is $9+6+3+6+4+2+3+2+1 = \boxed{36}.$ Extra challenge: If you know what "combinations" are in counting problems, try to find a much faster solution!
 *)

theorem
fixes rectangles :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. rectangles n = binomial n 2 ^ 2"

fixes dots :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y. dots x y = (if x < 4 \<and> y < 4 then 1 else 0)"
shows  "card {(x1, y1, x2, y2). dots x1 y1 = 1 \<and> dots x2 y2 = 1 \<and> x1 < x2 \<and> y1 < y2} = 36"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different rectangles with sides parallel to the grid can be formed by connecting four of the dots in a $4\times 4$ square array of dots, as in the figure below?

 We count the number of rectangles by cases, based on the side lengths of the rectangle: \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{Side lengths of rectangle} & \text{Number of rectangles} \\ \hline 1 \times 1 & 9 \\ \hline
 1 \times 2 & 6 \\ \hline 1 \times 3 & 3 \\ \hline 2 \times 1 & 6 \\ \hline 2 \times 2 & 4 \\ \hline 2 \times 3 & 2 \\ \hline 3 \times 1 & 3 \\ \hline 3 \times 2 & 2 \\ \hline 3 \times 3 & 1 \\ \hline \end{array}
 \] So the number of rectangles whose sides are parallel to the sides of the grid is $9+6+3+6+4+2+3+2+1 = \boxed{36}.$ Extra challenge: If you know what "combinations" are in counting problems, try to find a much faster solution!

How many rectangles can be formed where the corners of the rectangle are dots on this grid and the sides of the rectangles are parallel to the x and y axes? The final answer is 36.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes dots :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. i < 4 \<and> j < 4 \<longrightarrow> dots i j"
and h1 : "\<forall> i j k l. i < 4 \<and> j < 4 \<and> k < 4 \<and> l < 4 \<and> 
                     i \<noteq> k \<and> j \<noteq> l \<longrightarrow> 
                     (dots i j \<and> dots k l) \<or> (dots i l \<and> dots k j)"
shows  "\<exists> n. n = 36 \<and> (\<forall> I J K L. I \<noteq> K \<and> J \<noteq> L \<longrightarrow> 
                       (\<exists> i j k l. i < 4 \<and> j < 4 \<and> k < 4 \<and> l < 4 \<and> 
                        I = {i, k} \<and> J = {j, l} \<and> 
                        (dots i j \<and> dots k l) \<or> (dots i l \<and> dots k j)) \<longrightarrow> n)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different rectangles with sides parallel to the grid can be formed by connecting four of the dots in a $4\times 4$ square array of dots, as in the figure below?
[asy]size(2cm,2cm); for (int i=0; i<4; ++i) { for (int j=0; j<4; ++j) { filldraw(Circle((i, j), .05), black, black); } } [/asy] (Two rectangles are different if they do not share all four vertices.) The final Answer is 36
 ### Proof
 We count the number of rectangles by cases, based on the side lengths of the rectangle: \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{Side lengths of rectangle} & \text{Number of rectangles} \\ \hline 1 \times 1 & 9 \\ \hline
 1 \times 2 & 6 \\ \hline 1 \times 3 & 3 \\ \hline 2 \times 1 & 6 \\ \hline 2 \times 2 & 4 \\ \hline 2 \times 3 & 2 \\ \hline 3 \times 1 & 3 \\ \hline 3 \times 2 & 2 \\ \hline 3 \times 3 & 1 \\ \hline \end{array}
 \] So the number of rectangles whose sides are parallel to the sides of the grid is $9+6+3+6+4+2+3+2+1 = \boxed{36}.$ Extra challenge: If you know what "combinations" are in counting problems, try to find a much faster solution!
 *)

theorem
fixes dots :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. i < 4 \<and> j < 4 \<longrightarrow> dots i j"
and h1 : "\<forall> i j k l. i < 4 \<and> j < 4 \<and> k < 4 \<and> l < 4 \<and> 
                     i \<noteq> k \<and> j \<noteq> l \<longrightarrow> 
                     (dots i j \<and> dots k l) \<or> (dots i l \<and> dots k j)"
shows  "\<exists> n. n = 36 \<and> (\<forall> I J K L. I \<noteq> K \<and> J \<noteq> L \<longrightarrow> 
                       (\<exists> i j k l. i < 4 \<and> j < 4 \<and> k < 4 \<and> l < 4 \<and> 
                        I = {i, k} \<and> J = {j, l} \<and> 
                        (dots i j \<and> dots k l) \<or> (dots i l \<and> dots k j)) \<longrightarrow> n)"

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a 4x4 grid, every point is connected to every other point. For any two distinct points, they are either connected directly, or they are each connected to two distinct points. How many such connections are there? The final answer is 36.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes dots :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. i < 4 \<and> j < 4 \<longrightarrow> dots i j = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>i1 i2 j1 j2. i1 < 4 \<and> i2 < 4 \<and> j1 < 4 \<and> j2 < 4 \<and> i1 \<noteq> i2 \<and> j1 \<noteq> j2 \<longrightarrow> 
  (\<exists> a b c d. a < 4 \<and> b < 4 \<and> c < 4 \<and> d < 4 \<and> dots a b = 1 \<and> dots c d = 1 \<and> dots i1 j1 = 1 \<and> dots i2 j2 = 1)"
shows  "card {r. \<exists> i1 i2 j1 j2. i1 < 4 \<and> i2 < 4 \<and> j1 < 4 \<and> j2 < 4 \<and> i1 \<noteq> i2 \<and> j1 \<noteq> j2 \<and> dots i1 j1 = 1 \<and> dots i2 j2 = 1 \<and> r = (i1, j1, i2, j2)} = 36"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different rectangles with sides parallel to the grid can be formed by connecting four of the dots in a $4\times 4$ square array of dots, as in the figure below?
[asy]size(2cm,2cm); for (int i=0; i<4; ++i) { for (int j=0; j<4; ++j) { filldraw(Circle((i, j), .05), black, black); } } [/asy] (Two rectangles are different if they do not share all four vertices.) The final Answer is 36
 ### Proof
 We count the number of rectangles by cases, based on the side lengths of the rectangle: \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{Side lengths of rectangle} & \text{Number of rectangles} \\ \hline 1 \times 1 & 9 \\ \hline
 1 \times 2 & 6 \\ \hline 1 \times 3 & 3 \\ \hline 2 \times 1 & 6 \\ \hline 2 \times 2 & 4 \\ \hline 2 \times 3 & 2 \\ \hline 3 \times 1 & 3 \\ \hline 3 \times 2 & 2 \\ \hline 3 \times 3 & 1 \\ \hline \end{array}
 \] So the number of rectangles whose sides are parallel to the sides of the grid is $9+6+3+6+4+2+3+2+1 = \boxed{36}.$ Extra challenge: If you know what "combinations" are in counting problems, try to find a much faster solution!
 *)

theorem
fixes dots :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. i < 4 \<and> j < 4 \<longrightarrow> dots i j = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>i1 i2 j1 j2. i1 < 4 \<and> i2 < 4 \<and> j1 < 4 \<and> j2 < 4 \<and> i1 \<noteq> i2 \<and> j1 \<noteq> j2 \<longrightarrow> 
  (\<exists> a b c d. a < 4 \<and> b < 4 \<and> c < 4 \<and> d < 4 \<and> dots a b = 1 \<and> dots c d = 1 \<and> dots i1 j1 = 1 \<and> dots i2 j2 = 1)"
shows  "card {r. \<exists> i1 i2 j1 j2. i1 < 4 \<and> i2 < 4 \<and> j1 < 4 \<and> j2 < 4 \<and> i1 \<noteq> i2 \<and> j1 \<noteq> j2 \<and> dots i1 j1 = 1 \<and> dots i2 j2 = 1 \<and> r = (i1, j1, i2, j2)} = 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider a 4x4 grid where each cell has one dot. Given any two distinct cells (i1,j1) and (i2,j2), you can always find two other distinct cells (a,b) and (c,d) each containing one dot. What is the total number of distinct pairs of cells that you can choose? The final answer is 36.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "(int * int) set"
assumes h0 : "A = {(x,y). x \<in> {0..3} \<and> y \<in> {0..3}}"
shows  "card {(a,b,c,d). a<b \<and> c<d \<and> (a,c) \<in> A \<and> (b,d) \<in> A} = 36"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many different rectangles with sides parallel to the grid can be formed by connecting four of the dots in a $4\times 4$ square array of dots, as in the figure below?
[asy]size(2cm,2cm); for (int i=0; i<4; ++i) { for (int j=0; j<4; ++j) { filldraw(Circle((i, j), .05), black, black); } } [/asy] (Two rectangles are different if they do not share all four vertices.) The final Answer is 36
 ### Proof
 We count the number of rectangles by cases, based on the side lengths of the rectangle: \[ \begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline \text{Side lengths of rectangle} & \text{Number of rectangles} \\ \hline 1 \times 1 & 9 \\ \hline
 1 \times 2 & 6 \\ \hline 1 \times 3 & 3 \\ \hline 2 \times 1 & 6 \\ \hline 2 \times 2 & 4 \\ \hline 2 \times 3 & 2 \\ \hline 3 \times 1 & 3 \\ \hline 3 \times 2 & 2 \\ \hline 3 \times 3 & 1 \\ \hline \end{array}
 \] So the number of rectangles whose sides are parallel to the sides of the grid is $9+6+3+6+4+2+3+2+1 = \boxed{36}.$ Extra challenge: If you know what "combinations" are in counting problems, try to find a much faster solution!
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "(int * int) set"
assumes h0 : "A = {(x,y). x \<in> {0..3} \<and> y \<in> {0..3}}"
shows  "card {(a,b,c,d). a<b \<and> c<d \<and> (a,c) \<in> A \<and> (b,d) \<in> A} = 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: How many tuples of four integers $(a,b,c,d)$ are there such that $a<b$, $c<d$, and both $(a,c)$ and $(b,d)$ are pairs of integers with each component in the range from $0$ to $3$ inclusive? The final answer is $36$.

fixes n :: nat
